text.headline: Permissiviness
text.text:
What is wrong with Open source?

A timeline about OSS permissiviness.

background.alt: The Great Linux World Map 2.0 by Dedoimedo

text.headline: ARPANET first message sent
text.text: The first ARPANET message is sent between UCLA and Stanford, marking the birth of the internet and establishing the foundation for open networking protocols.

text.headline: MIT License formalized
text.text: The MIT License is formalized as one of the most permissive open source licenses, allowing unlimited freedom including proprietary use, becoming a template for maximum permissiveness.

text.headline: World Wide Web proposal
text.text: Tim Berners-Lee submits his proposal for the World Wide Web at CERN, creating the foundation for open web standards and information sharing.

text.headline: GNU Manifesto published, FSF founded
text.text: Richard Stallman publishes the GNU Manifesto and founds the Free Software Foundation (FSF) to promote free software principles, emphasizing user freedom over proprietary control.

text.headline: GPL v1.0 released
text.text: The GNU General Public License version 1.0 is released, establishing the first strong copyleft license that ensures derivative works remain free and open source.

text.headline: BSD License emerges as permissive alternative
text.text: The Berkeley Software Distribution license gains prominence, offering a permissive alternative to GPL that allows proprietary derivatives, establishing the foundation for the copyleft vs. permissive licensing divide.

text.headline: Linux kernel first released
text.text: Linus Torvalds announces the first version of the Linux kernel, initially released under his own license before adopting GPL v2 in 1992, establishing the model for collaborative kernel development.

text.headline: Linux adopts GPL v2
text.text: Linux kernel switches from Torvalds' original license to GPL v2, ensuring that all kernel contributions remain free and open source, setting a precedent for large collaborative projects.

text.headline: GPL v2.0 released
text.text: GPL version 2.0 is released, refining copyleft principles and becoming the most widely adopted strong copyleft license, used by the Linux kernel and thousands of projects.

text.headline: Apache HTTP Server released
text.text: The Apache HTTP Server is released, becoming one of the first major projects to use a permissive license, setting the stage for the Apache Software Foundation and permissive licensing model.

text.headline: Open Source Initiative founded
text.text: The Open Source Initiative (OSI) is founded by Eric Raymond and Bruce Perens, coining the term 'Open Source' as a business-friendly alternative to 'Free Software'.

text.headline: Apache Software Foundation founded
text.text: The Apache Software Foundation (ASF) is incorporated, promoting the Apache License as a permissive alternative to copyleft licenses and establishing a new governance model for open source projects.

text.headline: InnerSource coined by Tim O'Reilly
text.text: Tim O'Reilly coins the term 'InnerSource', describing the application of open source practices within organizations to improve collaboration and innovation.

text.headline: Web 2.0 Conference and open source adoption
text.text: Tim O'Reilly's Web 2.0 Conference popularizes the term. Companies like Google, Facebook, and others build their platforms on open source foundations while creating proprietary services on top.

text.headline: Steven Weber publishes The Success of Open Source
text.text: Steven Weber publishes The Success of Open Source, highlighting business opportunities in community-driven models and the economic advantages of permissive licensing for corporate adoption.

text.headline: Amazon Web Services launches
text.text: AWS launches with S3 and EC2, pioneering cloud computing and creating the infrastructure that will later enable cloud providers to monetize open source software without contributing back.

text.headline: GPL v3.0 released
text.text: GPL version 3.0 is released, addressing digital rights management and software patents, but faces resistance from projects like Linux kernel due to its additional restrictions.

text.headline: GNU AGPL v3.0 published
text.text: The GNU Affero General Public License (AGPL) v3.0 is published, extending copyleft to network-delivered software and attempting to close the 'web services loophole' in traditional GPL.

text.headline: Android Open Source Project launched
text.text: Google releases Android under Apache License 2.0, demonstrating how permissive licenses enable proprietary extensions while maintaining an open core, setting a template for mobile OS development.

text.headline: GitHub launched
text.text: GitHub is launched, democratizing access to Git repositories and making open source collaboration more accessible, while building a proprietary platform on top of open source tools.

text.headline: Andrew Lampitt coins 'Open Core'
text.text: Andrew Lampitt coins the term 'Open Core', describing a business model where a core product is open source, but additional features or services are proprietary.

text.headline: The shift toward permissive licensing accelerates
text.text: Major projects like Hadoop, and later OpenStack, adopt Apache-style licenses. Mike Olson argues that permissive licenses foster mass adoption over GPL's protective approach.

text.headline: Docker launches with open core model
text.text: Docker is released as open source, pioneering containerization while building a commercial platform around the open source engine, exemplifying the open core business model.

text.headline: HashiCorp founded
text.text: Mitchell Hashimoto and Armon Dadgar found HashiCorp, beginning with Vagrant and later building infrastructure tools like Terraform, Consul, and Vault under open source licenses.

text.headline: Growth of the Open Core model
text.text: The Open Core model gains popularity, with companies like GitHub, Docker, and others adopting it to balance community contributions with commercial interests.

text.headline: MongoDB launches with AGPL license
text.text: MongoDB is released under AGPL license to prevent cloud providers from offering it as a service without contributing back, but enforcement proves challenging as cloud adoption grows.

text.headline: Movable Type Open Source initiative ends.
Red Hat acquires CoreOS for $250M
text.text: Red Hat acquires CoreOS, gaining container expertise and the CoreOS Linux distribution, while consolidating its position in the enterprise Linux and container ecosystem.

text.headline: Microsoft acquires GitHub for $7.5B
text.text: Microsoft's acquisition of GitHub marks a shift toward 'Microsoft loves Linux' strategy, while raising concerns about a proprietary company controlling the world's largest open source platform.

text.headline: Redis modules adopt Apache 2.0 + Commons Clause
text.text: Redis Labs adds the Commons Clause to some Redis modules under Apache 2.0, restricting commercial use and sparking controversy about open source licensing.

text.headline: MongoDB adopts SSPL
text.text: MongoDB, Inc. introduces the Server Side Public License (SSPL), a controversial license that restricts cloud providers from offering MongoDB as a service without contributing back to the community.

text.headline: Confluent adopts Confluent Community License
text.text: Confluent introduces the Confluent Community License (CCL) for Kafka components, allowing source access but restricting commercial competitive use, sparking debate about 'open source washing'.

text.headline: Redis adopts RSAL and SSPL
text.text: Redis Labs transitions from Commons Clause to Redis Source Available License (RSAL) and SSPL for some modules, continuing to restrict cloud provider usage.

text.headline: CockroachDB adopts BUSL
text.text: Cockroach Labs adopts the Business Source License (BUSL) for CockroachDB, allowing free use with restrictions on competitive commercial services, introducing a time-based conversion to Apache 2.0.

text.headline: Sentry adopts BUSL
text.text: Sentry adopts the Business Source License (BUSL) for its core product, following the trend of developer tools companies seeking to prevent cloud providers from competing directly.

text.headline: IBM completes Red Hat acquisition for $34B
text.text: IBM completes its acquisition of Red Hat for $34 billion, the largest software acquisition in history, promising to maintain Red Hat's open source commitment and independence.

text.headline: AWS launches DocumentDB
text.text: AWS launches DocumentDB (MongoDB-compatible), prompting MongoDB's SSPL adoption. Later AWS responds to Elasticsearch's license change with OpenSearch fork.

text.headline: Elastic adopts dual license Elastic/SSPL
text.text: Elastic NV changes Elasticsearch and Kibana to dual licensing under Elastic License 2.0 and SSPL, restricting cloud provider usage and prompting AWS to fork OpenSearch.

text.headline: GitHub Copilot preview launched
text.text: GitHub launches Copilot, an AI coding assistant trained on billions of lines of public code, raising questions about fair use of open source code for commercial AI training.

text.headline: HashiCorp goes public
text.text: HashiCorp goes public on NASDAQ, raising $1.2 billion while maintaining its open source infrastructure tools, setting the stage for later licensing tensions with cloud providers.

text.headline: AI growth accelerates OSS exploitation
text.text: Permissive licenses fuel AI training datasets; massive code and data scraping becomes normalized across Google, Meta, OpenAI. Traditional IP protections struggle to keep pace.

text.headline: ChatGPT launches
text.text: OpenAI launches ChatGPT, demonstrating the power of large language models trained on vast amounts of open source code and data, raising questions about fair use and attribution.

text.headline: AI companies use permissive licenses without reciprocity
text.text: Large AI companies like OpenAI, Google, and Meta train models on vast amounts of open source code and data under permissive licenses, often without contributing back improvements or acknowledging sources.

text.headline: Red Hat restricts RHEL source code access
text.text: Red Hat announces it will only make RHEL source code available to paying customers, effectively ending public access and violating the spirit of GPL while technically remaining compliant.

text.headline: Rocky Linux and AlmaLinux adapt to RHEL changes
text.text: Rocky Linux and AlmaLinux, the CentOS replacements, announce they will shift from RHEL source to alternative sources like CentOS Stream and upstream packages to continue their RHEL-compatible distributions.

text.headline: HashiCorp changes Terraform to BSL
text.text: HashiCorp changes Terraform from Mozilla Public License 2.0 to Business Source License (BSL), restricting competitive commercial use and sparking controversy in the infrastructure-as-code community.

text.headline: OpenTofu initiative announced
text.text: In response to Terraform's license change, the OpenTofu initiative is announced by Gruntwork, Spacelift, and others, pledging to maintain a truly open source fork under the Linux Foundation.

text.headline: OpenTofu goes GA as Terraform fork
text.text: OpenTofu 1.6.0 is released as a stable, drop-in replacement for Terraform, demonstrating the community's ability to fork and maintain infrastructure tooling when licenses become restrictive.

text.headline: Valkey and KeyDB emerge as Redis forks
text.text: The Linux Foundation launches Valkey as an open source fork of Redis, while KeyDB and other community forks gain traction following Redis' license change.

text.headline: Redis changes to dual-license RSALv2/SSPL
text.text: Redis Ltd. announces that Redis 7.4 and later will be dual-licensed under RSALv2 and SSPL, ending Redis' open source era and prompting community forks like Valkey.

text.headline: GenAI disruption
text.text: Hyperscalers (MSFT/GitHub/OpenAI) form billion-dollar AI partnerships, cementing a downstream, permissive-dependent AI monopolization model.

text.headline: OSI releases Open Source AI Definition v1.0
text.text: The Open Source Initiative publishes the first official Open Source AI Definition, establishing criteria for what constitutes open source AI systems, including requirements for training data disclosure.

text.headline: Next-generation licensing debates intensify
text.text: As AI continues to reshape software development, new licensing models emerge to address training data rights, model weights distribution, and the tension between innovation and attribution in the age of generative AI.
